p.add: THE UTTER ROUTING of the whole Army of all the INDEPENDENTS & SECTARIES, with the Totall overthrow of their Hierarchy that New Bable, more groundless than that of the Prelates.
OR INDEPENDENCY not Gods ORDINANCE, in which all the frontires of the PRESBYTERY, with al the quarters of the same are Defended, against all Enemies.

And all the Forces of the three Generals and Commanders of the / Sectaries, Hanserde Knollys, J. S. & Henry B Burton are all dissipated, with all / their whibling Reserves, and the field of Truth still kept, viz. /
That the Presbyterian Government Dependent is Gods Or- / dinance, and not the Presbyterian Governmentâ–ª Independent. /

Unto which is annexed an Appendix in way of answer to Henry / Burton Clerk, one of his quondam fellow sufferers, in the which all his ca- / lumnies are wiped away by the sponge of innocency, and the Postscript Vin- / dicated; the honour also of all our renouned Generalls and Commanders / is Vindicated; the honour of the City of London; the honour of our brethren / the Scots; the honour likewise of all the Presbyters through the Kingdome / are Vindicated from the obloquie of all the Independents and Sectaries; / and their due prayses given unto them in their severall ranks and or- / ders, as next under God to have been the principall and primary / Repairers of our breach, and the Restorers of our pathes to / dwell in: the honour of all which the Sectaries / wholly and solely ascribe to their Party. /

By JOHN BASTVVICK Captain in the Presbyterian Army, / Dr in Physick and Phisitian in Ordinary to all the Ill-dependents and / Sectaries to sweat them with Arguments twice a year gratis, spring and / fall, who discovering their distempers and malidies finds by the severall / symptomes of their diseases that they are very unsound, root and branch, / and therefore ought (with their venemous and intolerable Toleration / of all Religions) to be shunned and avoyded as a company of infected per- / sons by all such as are sound in the faith. /
London, Printed by John Macock, and are to be sold by Michael Spark, / at the sign of the blue Bible in Green Arbour. 1646. /

div.head: To the Ingenuous READER.

It is not good that Å¿uch children as theÅ¿e are Å¿hould be Å¿uffered to have Å¿uch dangerous weapons in their fingers. It was
not thought fit by our Fore-fathers, who were commended for their wiÅ¿dome, that any PapiÅ¿ts Å¿hould Å¿it in the Parliament, and our ever to be honoured Worthies now Å¿itting in that great Conncell did not thinke it for the Kingdoms Å¿afety, that any PapiÅ¿t Å¿hould bee of the Kings Councell; and at the firÅ¿t Å¿itting of the Parliament no MonopoliÅ¿ts, or Gatherers of Ship-money, or Pattentees, or any Å¿uch creatures, though they were lawfully choÅ¿en by the people were Å¿uffered to Å¿it in Parliament, but were thruÅ¿t out as being Å¿uÅ¿pected they would prove bad inÅ¿truments to the State; and therfore I Å¿ay notwithÅ¿tanding the peoples election they were immediatly diÅ¿miÅ¿Å¿ed the great Councell, and the people were to make a new choyÅ¿e. For my own particular I will Å¿peake my conÅ¿cience in this point, and leave it to the judgement of all intelligible and wiÅ¿e men, Å¿uch as love their Religion and Countrey, I Å¿ee no reaÅ¿on that any Sectary whatÅ¿oever, whether Independent, Antinomian, AnabaptiÅ¿t, Seeker, &c. or any Fugitives that have ran over into Holland, or New-England to Å¿et up new Churches there, Å¿hould be Å¿uffered to Å¿it in the Great Councill of the Kingdome, which without doubt will with al their ability and power labour to maintaine their Å¿everall factions, all which tend to the ruine â€¢ of this State and Kingdom, and to the deÅ¿truction of all our liberties; and therefore I conceive they are as dangerous as ever the PapiÅ¿ts were; yea, the tenents of many of them are more deÅ¿tructive to all Government then ever thoÅ¿e of the IeÅ¿uits were, or the moÅ¿t inveterate PapiÅ¿t that ever yet put pen to paper, and if the PapiÅ¿ts were not Å¿uffered to Å¿it in Parliament, I Å¿hall ever beleeve it will not conÅ¿iÅ¿t with the Å¿afety of the Land, that any Sectary what ever Å¿hould Å¿it in the great Councell, eÅ¿pecially it being daily perceived that all the Sectaries through the land have their incouragement from Å¿ome of them to doe miÅ¿chiefe every where, but if the people through the Kingdom will not humbly perition the Parliament, that all Å¿uch with all Minors and Novices Å¿hould be put out of the Parliament, it being proclamed by God himÅ¿elfe as a curÅ¿e to that people who have children for their Princes, IÅ¿a. 3. whether they be children in reÅ¿pect of years or diÅ¿cretion, then it is a Å¿ad preÅ¿age of that kingdoms and countries ruin, where the people are not only divided amongÅ¿t themÅ¿elves, but their councels alÅ¿o, which they are through the whole land in all their Committees by reaÅ¿on of theÅ¿e Sectaries and Independents on all Å¿ides, who are

div.p:
THe ApoÅ¿tle Saint Paul in the fourth of the EpheÅ¿ians, exhorting all ChriÅ¿tians to walk worthy of the Vocation whereunto they were called, and to behave themÅ¿elves as beÅ¿eemed Brethren; wiÅ¿heth them with all lowlineÅ¿Å¿e and meekneÅ¿Å¿e, with long Å¿uffering and patience, to bear one with another in love: And uÅ¿eth a forceable Argument, to move them to brotherly kindneÅ¿Å¿e, BecauÅ¿e, Å¿aith he, there is but one body and one Å¿pirit and one hope of Salvation: We all worÅ¿hip one God, we are all conÅ¿ecrated to him with one BaptiÅ¿me, and we all hope for one and the Å¿elf-Å¿ame glory: Therefore as there is but one Lord, one faith, one BaptiÅ¿me; Å¿o be yee alÅ¿o of one minde, live in love, and keep the unity of the Spirit in the bond of Peace. If ever there was need of this exhortation, there is now Å¿ingular uÅ¿e of it, eÅ¿pecially in this diÅ¿tracted Nation wherein we live. For the diviÅ¿ion of a Kingdom is the ruine of it: the diviÅ¿ion of a family deÅ¿troys it: the diviÅ¿ion between brethren brings a confuÅ¿ion amongÅ¿t them. It hath ever bin obÅ¿erved, That diverÅ¿ity of judgment & opinion hath made a difference in affection. The difference between the Iews and the Samaritans in points of Religion, made the DiÅ¿ciples deÅ¿ire, That fire might come down from heaven to end that controverÅ¿ie.
The difference between us and the PapiÅ¿ts, and the diverÅ¿ity of opinions between us, made them, becauÅ¿e they could not bring down fire from heaven, fetch it out of hell, to blow up the Parliament; and becauÅ¿e that had not the deÅ¿ired effect, and the diverÅ¿ity of opinion Å¿til remaining, makes the difference of their affection from us Å¿o great, that nothing can expiate their indignation againÅ¿t us, but the utter internetion and deÅ¿truction of us all; and this and this only, next unto our own Å¿ins, is the cauÅ¿e of all thoÅ¿e fatall calamities this miÅ¿erable kingdome is now imbroyled with. And therefore, all care and diligence among brethren, Å¿hould be uÅ¿ed to get a right underÅ¿tanding one of another, and to move them to bear one with another, and ever to call to minde the Å¿aying of Abraham to Lot, Gen. 13. Let not us contend together for we are brethren. I am moÅ¿t aÅ¿Å¿ured, if there were a right underÅ¿tanding of the differences that are now among brethren, there could not be Å¿uch bitter expreÅ¿Å¿ions one againÅ¿t another, and Å¿uch alienation of affection as is now too frequent and too well known to the common enemy. We are commanded, If it be poÅ¿Å¿ible, as much as lies in us, to be in in peace with all men, Rom. 12. 18. And the fruits of diÅ¿cord are Å¿et down in the 5th of the Galathians verÅ¿e 15. If Å¿aith the ApoÅ¿tle ye bite and devoure one another, take heede yee be not conÅ¿umed one with another, and in the 20. verÅ¿e. Hatred Å¿aith the ApoÅ¿tle, varience, emulation, Å¿trife, hereÅ¿ies &c. and envyings are of the fleÅ¿h, and they that do Å¿uch things Å¿hall not enter into the Kingdome of God. A double miÅ¿ery follows thoÅ¿e that do theÅ¿e things, miÅ¿ery here, and miÅ¿ery hereafter, it excludes men out of heaven. The contemplation of the Å¿ad condition, that will inevitably come upon that Land, Kingdome, and Church, where thoÅ¿e variances and heart-burnings are, and where there is Å¿uch diverÅ¿ity of opinions, and by reaÅ¿on of them, Å¿uch difference in affection, put me chiefely upon this imployment, to Å¿ee and try, if by any poÅ¿Å¿ible meanes, I could, by Å¿hewing wherein the difference between the brethren lyeth, be an inÅ¿trument of a good accord amongÅ¿t them: reÅ¿olving with my Å¿elf by Gods aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance whatÅ¿oever others do, to obÅ¿erve to the uttermoÅ¿t of my abilities, the royall Law, Jan. 2. 8. I do conceive, that if there were a right underÅ¿tanding one of anothers opinions, the world would wonder there Å¿hould be Å¿uch invectives in every pamphlet one againÅ¿t another, and Å¿uch varience among thoÅ¿e that are joyned together
and that with nigheÅ¿t relations. The truth is, the miÅ¿-underÅ¿tanding of each others opinions and the miÅ¿-priÅ¿ian of each others intentions, is the onely cauÅ¿e of this diverÅ¿ity of affection which to the diÅ¿honour of God and of our holy profeÅ¿Å¿ion, and indeed to the diÅ¿grace of ChriÅ¿tian Religion, every where too much venteth it Å¿elfe. And therefore as Abraham Å¿aid unto Lot, Å¿o Å¿ay I to all thoÅ¿e that love the truth in Å¿incerity and wiÅ¿h the Peace of Zion; Let not us contend, eÅ¿pecially with evill language, for we are brethren; we have one father, we worÅ¿hip one God, we have one light, one truth, one way. And this I profeÅ¿Å¿e to all the world, That I contend not for victory, but for that ancient light, the faith once delivered unto the Saints, Iude 3. For that truth which we have heard from the beginning, 1 Iohn 2. ver. 14. for the old way, verÅ¿e 6. The way the truth and the life, Ioh. 14. and for the honour of that Church againÅ¿t which the gates of hell can never prevaile; in the which there are all thoÅ¿e undeceiveable marks, as are able for ever to declare her to be built upon the foundation of Peter, in which the GoÅ¿pell of JeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t is purely and Å¿incerely both preached and beleeved, and where the Sacraments are rightly adminiÅ¿tred, and in the which there is the true invocation of God, and all other requiÅ¿ites that make her a true Church; and from which there is no juÅ¿t cauÅ¿e of Å¿eparation. That I have dedicated this TreatiÅ¿e to no man, nor Å¿ought the patronage of any Authority, no mortall creature I preÅ¿ume, will blame me, knowing my ReaÅ¿ons. For writing in defence of the Prerogative Royall of Kings, againÅ¿t Papall UÅ¿urpation; I dedicated my booke unto the King of great Britaine, France, and Ireland, Å¿uppoÅ¿ing my Å¿elfe Å¿afe under his protection, whoÅ¿e honour and imperiall dignity I maintain: but all men know, what miÅ¿ery to the ruine of me, my wife, and many Å¿mall children came upon me by it, through the power and exorbitant authority of the Prelates: Å¿o that for my duty and Loyalty to the King, I had a priÅ¿on for my reward, and the Å¿cornes and contumelies of the world to comfort me in it. And when I moÅ¿t humbly petitioned his highneÅ¿Å¿e, complaining againÅ¿t the injuÅ¿tice done me, and moÅ¿t Å¿ubmiÅ¿Å¿ively Å¿upplicated his MajeÅ¿ty (who was the CaeÅ¿ar to whom only I could then appeal) that he would be pleaÅ¿ed to grant me one of theÅ¿e humble requeÅ¿ts, either That his MajeÅ¿ty would be pleaÅ¿ed, but for one houre to give me a hearing of my juÅ¿t defence; or if
that could not be granted, That at leÅ¿t he would then grant me that liberty in his Kingdome, that he denyed not to Crows and Kites and other Vermine, that I might provide for my young ones; and if his highneÅ¿Å¿e would not be pleaÅ¿ed to condeÅ¿cend unto either of the former juÅ¿t demands, That then he would give me leave to depart the Kingdom, and to go into any other Country where I might enjoy my Liberty and provide for my poore diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿ed family. I am moÅ¿t aÅ¿Å¿ured there was never a more equall Petition put up to any Prince in the world, yet his MajeÅ¿tie vouchÅ¿afed not to yeeld unto any of theÅ¿e my requeÅ¿ts, nor to any other Petition put up either by my poor diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿ed wife or calamitous children; Å¿o that without any wrong unto his MajeÅ¿ty, I may truely Å¿ay, That Paul found more favour from a Heathen Roman CaeÅ¿ar, then I had from a ChriÅ¿tian King, the defender of the faith. After I Å¿aw all poÅ¿Å¿ibility of releefe was now taken from me, I writ my Apology to the BiÅ¿hops themÅ¿elves, diÅ¿covering unto them their unjuÅ¿t proceedings in their Courts, and their unrighteous dealings towards my Å¿elfe, and gave them my reaÅ¿ons of all I Å¿pake, without any offenÅ¿ive language and without any perturbation of Spirit; and Dedicated this my Booke to the Lords of his MajeÅ¿ties Privy Councell, expecting ayde and reliefe from them, and indeed I had no hope of Å¿uccour from any other, nor knew none to whom I could better apply my Å¿elfe, earneÅ¿tly imploring their patronage; but they, as it is well knowne, of Patrons became my unjuÅ¿t Judges, and after they had made me a Å¿pectacle to Men and Angells, and expoÅ¿ed me to the Å¿corne and ludibry of the world, Å¿ent me into baniÅ¿hment, where I lived a living death and a dying life, and Å¿uffered Å¿uch intolerable miÅ¿ery of all Å¿orts, as would exceed beliefe to relate; and I am moÅ¿t confident, if all the particulars were truly known, the world never heard the like, and there I had ended my dolefull life, had not God of his infinite mercy called this Parliament, and put into their hearts to redeem me from my captivity; for the which incomparable favour, I do, as of duty I am ever bound, profeÅ¿Å¿e my Å¿elfe to the laÅ¿t drop of my blood to be their Å¿ervant in the Lord, and in all their moÅ¿t juÅ¿t and honourable imployments; I hope, with all fidelity to anÅ¿wer to the expectation of the world, and Å¿hall in life and death Å¿hew my Å¿elfe to be one, that without all by-reÅ¿pects Å¿hall ever aime at the glory of Godâ–ª the honour of them and my
Country, and the common good of all: and Å¿hall never by Gods aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance do any thing in their concernment, that Å¿hall be unbeÅ¿eeming a Man and a ChriÅ¿tian. Now becauÅ¿e by my Å¿ad experience, I found that I could neither from King nor Nobles have protection, I reÅ¿olved never any more in Gods matters, to Å¿hroud my Å¿elf under any covert but Divine Providence, and that, I with an aÅ¿Å¿ured confidence promiÅ¿e my Å¿elf, eÅ¿pecially when I now maintain the prerogative royall of the King of Saints, & King of Kings, the Lord JeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, Who is our Lawgiver, upon whoÅ¿e Å¿houlders the government of his Church is laid, who is the wonderfull CounÅ¿eller, the Prince of peace; whoÅ¿e dignity and royalty in all this diÅ¿pute between me and Mr. Walter Mountague, I have to the uttermoÅ¿t of my power maintained, under the Å¿hadow of whoÅ¿e wings I have ever found there is only Å¿afety; whoÅ¿e bleÅ¿Å¿ed aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance, in all calamities, they that truÅ¿t in him, may be moÅ¿t aÅ¿Å¿i
â€¢ ed of. His patronage now and his defence, is my Å¿hield, whoÅ¿e cauÅ¿e and the honour of whoÅ¿e kingdome at this time I contend for. And howÅ¿oever, in all my life, in all humane learning, I was never Å¿o wedded to my own reÅ¿olves, butâ–ª upon better reaÅ¿on I could eaÅ¿ily be divorced from them, yet in Gods matters, if an Angell Å¿hould come from Heaven and teach me, that, that there were another way to happineÅ¿Å¿e, then by that new and living way, the blood of JeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, who was the LambeÅ¿laine from the beginning of the world, I would count him Anathema. Or if an Angel Å¿hould tell me there were a new way of worÅ¿hipping God, and Å¿erving him, then that which God himÅ¿elf hath Å¿et down in his holy Word, I would account him accurÅ¿ed; for I have learned to believe God and Faith upon their word and bond, without any either Angelicall or Humane reaÅ¿on, or the authority of Coun
â€¢ els and Fathers: and whatÅ¿oever I finde a warrant in Gods Word for, I have learned to cleave cloÅ¿e to it againÅ¿t all humane reaÅ¿on, Å¿uppoÅ¿ing Å¿uch men none of Gods, nor Faiths, trueÅ¿t friends that will not believe them upon their own word and bond, except they have reaÅ¿on, humane authority, Councels, and Fathers, and â€¢ aine traditions joyned with them for Å¿ureties. Again, if any man Å¿hould go about to perÅ¿wade me, that there were any other government eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed in the Church of God, then an AriÅ¿tocraticall and a Presbyterian one, I Å¿hould notwithÅ¿tanding all humane reaÅ¿on to the contrary, Å¿ubmit my Å¿elf to that kind of government,
as being moÅ¿t confidently aÅ¿Å¿ured that it is warranted in Gods Word; which all ChriÅ¿tians are bound for ever to make the Rule and Square, both of our faith, manners and government. And here I muÅ¿t minde all thoÅ¿e that Å¿hall read this Book, that this is no new opinion of mine, but that which I have once and again Å¿uffered forâ–ª and if ever they have read my Elenchus religionis papiÅ¿ticiae, or my Flagellum pontificis, or my Apologie, or any of my Latine Books, in all thoÅ¿e they will finde, that the cauÅ¿e of all my Å¿ufferings was this, and this only, That I maintained that all Churches were to be governed by an AriÅ¿tocraticall and Presbyterian government, which in thoÅ¿e Books I have clearly and fully (through Gods aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance) made good. Yea, in in my anÅ¿wer to the Bill of Information put up againÅ¿t me in the Star-chamber, they Å¿hall have Å¿ome reaÅ¿ons I gave there, of this my tenent, to the Lords of his MajeÅ¿ties Hrivie Councell, and Judges in the Star-chamber; Å¿o that I Å¿tand to my principles and am no Å¿tarter. And if then amongÅ¿t Gods people it was thought an opinion worthy the Å¿uffering for, and my ChriÅ¿tian brethren deemed me worthy of honour for it, and afforded me their prayers, and Å¿hewed me and mine in all our diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿es, many curteÅ¿ies, when we found little favour from our own brethren (which their humanity I muÅ¿t never forget, but with all due thankfulneÅ¿Å¿e for ever acknowledge) I Å¿ay, if then this my opinion was thought Orthodox, and worthy of their applauÅ¿e, I Å¿ee no good reaÅ¿on why a truth then Å¿hould not be counted a truth now; for the Word of God out of which I had it, is the Å¿ame, and if it were good then, it is good now: for the change of mens minds cannot change the truth, but it muÅ¿t be ever truth: but this my opinion I learned out of Gods Word then which Å¿hall be for ever, by his gracious aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance the warrant of my beliefe and practice. This Word therefore, I deÅ¿ire all my ChriÅ¿tian Brethren, in the deciding of this queÅ¿tion now agitated, amongÅ¿t Gods people and his faithfull Å¿ervants, concerning Church-government, to take into their hands, and with thoÅ¿e noble B â€¢ reans to Å¿it down and examine whatÅ¿oever Å¿hall be Å¿aid on either Å¿ide according to the holy Scrigtures: and I intreat them alÅ¿o to lay aÅ¿ide all paÅ¿Å¿ion (which Religion has no need of) and all vain-glory and bitterneÅ¿Å¿e, which is a diÅ¿honour to our holy calling, and in the Å¿pirit of meekneÅ¿Å¿e, and with a Virgin judgement, not raviÅ¿ht with any previous or anticipated opinion, to
come and approach to the Altar of truth, and Å¿o conÅ¿ider and examine, which of thoÅ¿e two opinions the Brethren on both Å¿ides now Å¿acrifice themÅ¿elves unto, be the offering that will beÅ¿t endure the firy-tryall, 1 Cor. 3. 13, 14, 15. viz. Whether the Presbyterian government Dependent, or a Presbyterian government Independent, both now laid upon the Altar, be the acceptableÅ¿t Å¿ervice, and beÅ¿t pleaÅ¿ing Å¿acrifice. This is granted on all Å¿ides, and of neceÅ¿Å¿ity it muÅ¿t be yeilded unto, that that Oblation is the beÅ¿t and moÅ¿t acceptable that is offered up by faith, without which it is impoÅ¿Å¿ible to pleaÅ¿e God, and that Å¿acrifice only is offered up by faith, which is according to his Word, and has its warrant from his revealed will, which is the rule both for worÅ¿hip and the government of his Church we are to be guided by. The Brethren on both Å¿ides agree about the rule in deciding of this CoutroverÅ¿ie and make the written word the rule. They agree alÅ¿o about the materials, both acknowledging a Presbytery, the difference between them is only, about the mould and manner of the offering. I will therefore Å¿tate the queÅ¿tions between us, and Å¿hew wherein we differ, and then Å¿etâ–ª down my own opinion with my reaÅ¿ons, and after endeavour to be a Moderator for the determining of this unhappy difference, which hath been an occaÅ¿ion of Å¿o much rejoycing to the common Enemy.

There is a two-fold queÅ¿tion between us, they call the Presbyterians, and our Brethren they tearme Independents. The firÅ¿t is concerning the government of the Church, vi â€¢ . whether it be Presbyterian Dependent, or Presbyterian Independent. The Å¿econd queÅ¿tion is, concerning the gathering of Churches: but of that in its due place. The firÅ¿t queÅ¿tion is whether many Congregations or ChriÅ¿tian AÅ¿Å¿emblies (commonly called Churches in our dialect) in the which there are all the acts of worÅ¿hip, or all Ordinances, as the pure preaching of the GoÅ¿pell, the due and right adminiÅ¿tration of the Sacraments, the true invocation of God, DiÅ¿cipline rightly executed, and all other performances, which make for the eÅ¿Å¿ence and form of a true Church, and in the which aÅ¿Å¿emblies likewiÅ¿e, they have all Å¿uch officers and helps of Governmentâ–ª as in their Å¿everall places being rightly imployed, may Å¿erve for the edification of the Å¿ame, and mutuall comfort and benefit of each other, and the preÅ¿ervation ofall, as Presbyters, doth preaching and ruling and Deacons, and all other Officers; I Å¿ay
the queÅ¿tion between us and the brethren is, Whether all theÅ¿e Å¿everall Congregations and AÅ¿Å¿emblies, may be accounted but one Church, or make but one Church within their Precincts; and be to be under the government and rule of one Presbytery, or a Councell or Colledge of many Presbyters together, upon which, all the Congregations and Å¿everall AÅ¿Å¿emblies under it are to depend; and to which in all weighty buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿es they are to appeal, for any injury or conceived wrong, or Å¿candall; or for redreÅ¿Å¿e of any abuÅ¿es in Doctrine or manners, and for the exerciÅ¿ing of Church-DiÅ¿cipline upon incorrigable and Å¿candalous offenders; as admonition for giving offence, Å¿uÅ¿penÅ¿ion from the Ordinances till amendment and reformation; or if obÅ¿tinate, Excommunion? Or whether every one of thoÅ¿e particular Congregations, or AÅ¿Å¿emblies be they never Å¿o Å¿mall, Å¿everally or conÅ¿idered a part, and by themÅ¿elves be Independent; that is to Å¿ay, have full and plenary authority within themÅ¿elves, without reference to this, or any other great Councell or Presbytery, for tranÅ¿acting or determining all differences about faith or manners amongÅ¿t themÅ¿elves, or for the redreÅ¿Å¿ing of any grievances or abuÅ¿es, or the exerciÅ¿ing of the power of DiÅ¿cipline or juriÅ¿diction, and from the which there is no appeal for relief, though the parties offended conceive they have never Å¿o much injury or wrong done them? q.p: Object. It may poÅ¿Å¿ibly here be objected, how will it appeare that Å¿o Å¿mall a number as two or three joyned together in the fellowÅ¿hip of the GoÅ¿pell, do conÅ¿titute a viÅ¿ible Church?

AnÅ¿w. I do not Å¿ay that it is alwaies Å¿o taken, for becauÅ¿e the church doth frequently conÅ¿iÅ¿t of many; but this I Å¿ay, that it may be Å¿o taken, as the very coherence of the words Å¿hews.

And during the time I was in the eÅ¿tate of nature, God by his preventing and reÅ¿trayning grace kept mee from living or delighting in Å¿uch Å¿innes, whereby any could truly charge me for a Å¿candalous Walker. Therefore in the preÅ¿ence of this great God, who of his free grace hath Elected, Called, and JuÅ¿tified me through faith in his Son the Lord IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, not Å¿uffering me to turne aÅ¿ide, neither to the right hand nor to the left, out of the paths of truth and that lead to holineÅ¿Å¿e: I Å¿olemnly proteÅ¿t, and hold out my ProteÅ¿tation to the view of the whole World; you have moÅ¿t injuriouÅ¿ly wronged mee, in proclaiming mee to be Å¿uch an one; For I am as blameleÅ¿Å¿e and free from your calumniations, as Naboth was from wicked Iezabels deÅ¿perate plot, wherewith Å¿he tooke away his life, 1 King 21. 8, 9, 10. &c. and as innocent as JoÅ¿eph, from the falÅ¿e accuÅ¿ations brought againÅ¿t him by his wanton, laÅ¿civious, and Å¿hameleÅ¿Å¿e miÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿e, Gen. 39. 14, 15, 16, 17, 18, which
makes me bold to Å¿ay, neither the Devill, any of his InÅ¿truments, no nor your Å¿elfe, in the words of truth, can prove the things whereof you have accuÅ¿ed mee.

I Å¿hal here conclude my anÅ¿wer to this Charge with the ApoÅ¿tle Paul's words, 1 Cor. 4. 3, 4, 5. But with me it is a very Å¿mall thing that I Å¿hould be judged of you, or of mans judgement: yea, I judge not mine own Å¿elfe. For I know nothing by my Å¿elfe, yet am I not hereby juÅ¿tified: but he that judgeth me is the Lord. Therefore judge nothing before the time, untill the Lord come, who both will bring to light the hidden things of darkneÅ¿Å¿e, and will make manifeÅ¿t the Councels of the heart: and then Å¿hall every man have praiÅ¿e of God.

Brother, I have been the larger in my reply to this particular becauÅ¿e it is the foundation and main pillar that may Å¿eem to hold up all your other Calumnies; for if you could prove me to be a Scandalous walker, to the Å¿hame of the very name of ChriÅ¿tian Religion, then men might eaÅ¿ily be perÅ¿waded to beleeve your whole Charg; But the foundation being Å¿o rotten and unfound, the Å¿uperÅ¿tructure cannot poÅ¿Å¿ibly Å¿tand.
I now proceed to the fourth particular, and my AnÅ¿wer thereunto is, that no man of truth, worth, and piety, can juÅ¿tly taxe me either with baÅ¿eneÅ¿Å¿e or barbariÅ¿m.

For the fifth particular, it is elevated very high, and becauÅ¿e you have in this exceedingly beÅ¿tirr'd your Å¿elfe, I am neceÅ¿Å¿itated (for the clearing my Å¿elf, & to vindicate the truth of what I have written) to be Å¿omewhat large in my reply, that I may fully anÅ¿wer the Charge you bring againÅ¿t me therein, which is very great: viz. You accuÅ¿e me to be one of the greateÅ¿t Incendiaries in the Land, and to prove this you quote two paÅ¿Å¿ages in one of my bookes, and you bring them as two witneÅ¿Å¿es; for the confirmation thereof, the firÅ¿t is in my Preface pag. 28. the Å¿econd in my PoÅ¿tcript pag. 45. Now theÅ¿e two witneÅ¿Å¿es of your own (Å¿ay you) want but a Judge judicially to pronounce Å¿entence whether theÅ¿e words be not of an Incendiary nature and that in a high degree: For who's Å¿o blind as doth not clearly Å¿ee theÅ¿e fiery flaÅ¿hes and flames to fly in the face of that Army which God hath honoured with many Crowns of admirable Victories both at York, at NaÅ¿eby, and at Lamport, with the recovery of LeiceÅ¿ter, Bridgewater, Bath, &c. Å¿o as God hath made this despiÅ¿ed Army, the PreÅ¿ervative of City and Country, the
Repairer of the breach, the ReÅ¿torer of the pathes to dwell in. Thus you.

Brother, this accuÅ¿ation hath a Tower raiÅ¿ed on the Å¿ame BaÅ¿is the whole Fabrick of your Charge is founded upon, and the foundation being deep, you dare build Å¿o high as (if it were poÅ¿Å¿ible) to over-top truth, not fearing the fall of your Babel; but God, who is Truth it Å¿elfe, Å¿eeing the evill of your intentions, hath confounded your Language, as he did thoÅ¿e builders who Å¿ought to get themÅ¿elves a name, Gen. 11. 4, 5, 6, 7. And therefore it will fall notwithÅ¿tanding the height of its Tower. O what a confuÅ¿ed relation have you made to prove me an Incendiary! I aÅ¿Å¿ure you in all you have Å¿aid, men of the cleareÅ¿t eye-Å¿ight, nay were they Eagleey'd, they can never diÅ¿cerne any truth where with you make good that Charge which you Å¿ay is Å¿o conÅ¿picuous to the view of all men: For thoÅ¿e two witneÅ¿Å¿es that you produce, thus they Å¿peak (Preface pag. 28. Å¿aith) They have the Å¿word now in their hand, and they think their party Å¿trong enough to encounter any adverÅ¿e and oppoÅ¿ing party, and they profeÅ¿Å¿e they care not how Å¿oon they come to cutting of throats, and Å¿peak of nothing but the Å¿laughtering and bunchering of the PreÅ¿byterians, and therefore there is juÅ¿t cauÅ¿e given us to think we may expect better quarter from the very enemies, then from the Independents. (PoÅ¿tÅ¿cript teÅ¿tifieth) that the Independents boast they have Å¿uch a party in the Kingdome, (if their own words may be credited) as they now think by the Å¿word to be able to make their own laws; and have been frequently heard Å¿ay, that they had many abbettors in the AÅ¿Å¿embly, and in both HouÅ¿es of Parliament and in many parts through the Kingdome, beÅ¿ides in all the Armies; and they were all reÅ¿olved to have the liberty of their conÅ¿ciences, or elÅ¿e they would make uÅ¿e of their Å¿words, which they have already in their hands. So that moÅ¿t certain it is the Religion of too too many of them is a meer faction, &c. Now what theÅ¿e two have affirmed, can be corroborated by other witneÅ¿Å¿es, and if in your account he be an Incendiary that in deteÅ¿tation thereof hath Å¿et down their words by way of repetition to diÅ¿cover the danger of permitting Å¿uch lawleÅ¿Å¿e Å¿pirits to go on in their unwarrantable wayes, what great Incendiartes are they that have imagined Å¿uch things in their hearts and boldly Å¿poken thoÅ¿e words with their mouths? For out of the abundance of the heart the mouth Å¿peaketh, Matth. 12. 34. Luke 6. 45. as it can be proved Independents have
done; and Å¿o much the two witneÅ¿Å¿es you Å¿pake of Å¿aid; and no more; for they accuÅ¿ed not that Army, which God hath honoured with many Crowns of admirable Victories, &c. But you Å¿ay, they caÅ¿t fiery flaÅ¿hes and flames which do fly in the face of that Army, &c. Truly this is no other but a falÅ¿e Comment made by your Å¿elfe, from which you draw an evill inference, and then you cry out (as a man overcome with paÅ¿Å¿ion) Å¿aying, theÅ¿e words are not to be born: but I leave (Å¿ay you) the judgement thereof to the wiÅ¿dome and juÅ¿tice of the Parliament, whoÅ¿e former freeing of you extends not to cleare your words from being Incendiary. Thus farre you.

Brother, I profeÅ¿Å¿e I am heartily Å¿orry to Å¿ee that you my Quondam Fellow Sufferer Å¿hould Å¿o much forget your Å¿elfe, as not only bitterly, unworthily, and moÅ¿t falÅ¿ly thus to inveigh againÅ¿t mee, but alÅ¿o to inÅ¿inuate into the Parliament, as if they could not manifeÅ¿t their wiÅ¿dome and juÅ¿tice, except they paÅ¿Å¿e their judgement, and cenÅ¿ure me according to your bill of Information. This violent proÅ¿ecution, and your Canterburian expreÅ¿Å¿ions, make not me alone, but all other Å¿olid ChriÅ¿tians wonder at your Å¿pirit: for you may pleaÅ¿e to call to mind, how one once profeÅ¿Å¿ed he would not paÅ¿Å¿e any Å¿entence againÅ¿t You, my Brother Prynne, and My Å¿elfe, but left us as he Å¿aid to the wiÅ¿dome and juÅ¿tice of the Court, which was in the judgement of all that heard his whole Å¿peech, to pronounce us Å¿o highly guilty, that if the Lords there preÅ¿ent, did not Å¿everely cenÅ¿ure us, they would Å¿hew themÅ¿elves neither wiÅ¿e, nor juÅ¿t. This preÅ¿ident you have exactly followed againÅ¿t me but it will never Crown your head with honour; and for the Parliament, it is their glory to Å¿light troubleÅ¿ome informers: for Å¿hould they hearken to every information invented and drawn up by the unÅ¿atisfied and turbulent Å¿pirits of Å¿ome Independents, it would cloud their wiÅ¿dome, and totally eclipÅ¿e the Å¿hining of their JuÅ¿tice in our Horizon: But you cannot there obtain an Order to have your Bill taken pro confeÅ¿Å¿o, and gain Å¿o much of the Parliament that I Å¿hould not anÅ¿wer for my Å¿elfe; therefore I may and will Å¿peak for my Å¿elfe in my juÅ¿t defence and Å¿hew how unjuÅ¿tly you have accuÅ¿ed me; And here I deny your Charg in every particular circumÅ¿tance.

But before I returne my anÅ¿wer thereunto, you having given me Å¿uch a Theam to Å¿peak upon, as the due acknowledgement of
Gods goodneÅ¿Å¿e in raiÅ¿ing us up deliverers when City and Country were Å¿orely afflicted and heavily oppreÅ¿Å¿ed on every Å¿ide, in Å¿peaking of Gods providentiall care and Å¿everall actings in way of mercy to his people, I cannot omit (by way of thankfulneÅ¿Å¿e to God and men) to declare how that in the firÅ¿t place City and Country are deeply ingaged for ever next unto divine goodneÅ¿Å¿e to honour and highly eÅ¿teem thoÅ¿e Lords, Knights, Gentlemen, and Citizens who in the beginning of the Kingdomes troubles, like the Governours of IÅ¿rael and the Princes of IÅ¿Å¿achar did offer themÅ¿elves willingly among the people. Judges 5. 9. 15. whoÅ¿e very appearing in the cauÅ¿e was then of Å¿uch concernment, that as it made the hearts of all who were truly godly to praiÅ¿e God for them, Å¿o thereby God made them the preÅ¿ervative of City and Country; InÅ¿omuch that upon Å¿erious conÅ¿ideration we Å¿hall find, that thoÅ¿e Noble Lords, and all thoÅ¿e brave Commanders that adhered to them, who as Zebulon and Napthali jeoparded their lives unto the death, in the high places of the field, and expoÅ¿ed themÅ¿elves to reproach, Judges 5. 18. are not to be over lookt, and their gallant undertakings obÅ¿cured under a Sable cloud of unthankfulneÅ¿Å¿e, nor to be buried in the grave of Oblivion.

For, when the Kingdome was in greateÅ¿t danger, then God made uÅ¿e of them to preÅ¿erve Citie and Countrey, rayÅ¿ing an Army by Land, and Å¿etting forth a Navie at Å¿ea, under the commands of the Right Honourable, thrice IlluÅ¿trious, Faithfull, Valiant, and for ever to be highly honoured Lords, Robert Earle of EÅ¿Å¿ex, and Robert Earle of Warwicke, whom hee made by Å¿ea, and land, inÅ¿trumentall for the good and welfare of the Kingdome; and the truth is, at this day, neither preÅ¿ervation nor Å¿afety could have beene expected in Citie and Countrey, as things then Å¿tood, had not theÅ¿e two Renowned Lords and Heroes, Å¿o nobly and undauntedly appeared in the cauÅ¿e, & undertaken the charge, and care upon them, one to be Admirall of the Navie at Å¿ea, the other to be Generall of the Parliaments forces by Land: For this their undertaking was in Å¿uch a juncture of time, that had they out of Å¿elfe reÅ¿pects declined it, unleÅ¿Å¿e the Lord by a miracle had withÅ¿tood and over-throwne our enemies, Citie and Countrey (in all probability) long before this time, would have beene over-run, and poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed by them, and no man Å¿hould now have had peace in his going out or comming in: But by the valour, vigilancie, and faithfulneÅ¿Å¿e of
our then Noble Admirall, our Seas were Å¿afe-guarded, by which meanes, forraine enemies were awed, home-bred enemies weakened, by Å¿urprizing many Ships, Armes, Ammunition, InÅ¿truments, and Preparations for warre, which were Å¿ent over into England, for the deÅ¿truction of Citie and Countrey; beÅ¿ieged Townes were by him relieved, as Lyme, Plymouth, &c. So that God made that Noble Lord by Seaâ–ª the preÅ¿ervative of Citie, and Countrey, which lay open ready to be deÅ¿troyed by cruell and bloody enemies. And as the Earle of War wicke by Sea, Å¿o had not the Earle of EÅ¿Å¿ex, being Generall of the Parliaments Armies by Land, beene an experienced Commander, faithfull to their cauÅ¿e, and with a moÅ¿t Heroick and undaunted courage Å¿tood to the Battle at Edge-hill (when by report whole Regiments ran away, and through feare deÅ¿erted him) there now would have beene no Å¿afety in Citie and Countrey. What had become of Citie and Countrey when BriÅ¿tow was loÅ¿t, aud GlouceÅ¿ter cloÅ¿ely beÅ¿ieged, which though it was a long time, even beyond expectation valiantly maintained by Colonell MaÅ¿Å¿ie the then Governour thereof, that ever to be honoured Gentleman, had it not by the care and valour of that Noble Lord beene Å¿eaÅ¿onably relieved, it could not poÅ¿Å¿ibly have held longer out, but muÅ¿t have beene delivered up unto the Enemie, and have beene made a prey for the Spoylers, and then what peace or Å¿afetie would Citie or Countrie have injoyed? In a word, what had become of Citie and Countrie, if that Army under his command, and Å¿o gallantly incouraged by him had not incountered the enemies of our peace, and through Gods mercie victoriouÅ¿ly diÅ¿comfited their Forces Å¿everall times, as at Newbury, and at other places?

Truly it is by all, that will not manifeÅ¿t to the whole world that they are ungratefull to God, and unthankefull to men, ever to bee acknowledged, that the Earle of EÅ¿Å¿ex, the Earle of War wicke, with thoÅ¿e gallant Commanders, and Citizens in that Armie, and Navie commanded by them, deÅ¿erve the firÅ¿t place of honour to be our preÅ¿ervers, Å¿ome of whoÅ¿e names I Å¿hall by and by Å¿et downe, though I can never Å¿ufficiently Å¿et forth their praiÅ¿es and their merits, and to theÅ¿e many other worthy Generals muÅ¿t bee added with all thoÅ¿e gallant Officers and Commanders under them, who commanded Å¿everall Armies, Regiments and Companies by CommiÅ¿sions from the Earle of EÅ¿Å¿ex: as the
Right Honourable, thrice IlluÅ¿trious, Faithfull, Valiant, and for ever to be highly honoured Lord.

All theÅ¿e and many hundreds more, whoÅ¿e names are unknown to mee, none of the which were then Independents, yet whoÅ¿e fame, for their noble chivalry and gallantry in all their imployments, will live when Mortality is dead; and truly for every one of theÅ¿e I have by name Å¿et downe, they are all of them men accompliÅ¿hed for all heroicall vertue, and Å¿uch as of whom Å¿everally
for their moÅ¿t excellent Å¿ervice, and Å¿everall engagements, even in difficulteÅ¿t timesâ–ª I could make a large DiÅ¿courÅ¿e, and yet that would not Å¿ufficiently Å¿et forth their due prayÅ¿es; for theÅ¿e firÅ¿t Actors under-went the heate of the day, and by their valour quelled the Enemy, as I have heard the Cavaliers themÅ¿elves acknowledge; and therefore all thoÅ¿e noble Heroes and gallant Commanders, as I Å¿aid before, have all of them primary right to that title IÅ¿ay 58. 12. to be called the Repairers of the breach, the reÅ¿torers of our pathes to dwell in; for as much as when we were in great fears and unavoydable ruin did Å¿eem to threaten both Church and State, then God moved all their hearts to appear in his cauÅ¿e, and made them the preÅ¿ervative of City and Country, WhoÅ¿e undertakings, performances, faithfulneÅ¿Å¿e, valour, and Noble proweÅ¿Å¿e, ought to be predicated, and recorded, that future generations may know their deliverers, and admire Gods goodneÅ¿Å¿e who gave them magnanimous Å¿pirits to appear and expoÅ¿e themÅ¿elves to danger for the Kingdomes Å¿afety in Å¿uch a time, when the people were generally Å¿ecure, ignorant of the miÅ¿eries that were like to befall them, and their poÅ¿terity, and Å¿o deluded with promiÅ¿es and proteÅ¿tations that the greater part in moÅ¿t Counties, withÅ¿tood their own good, the peace and welfare of Church and State. And when the men in England lived delicately, and had been Å¿o long dandled in the lap of peace, that very few, none in compariÅ¿on, had ever Å¿een the formidable face of a reall fighting Army, nor had ever beheld the furious countenance of bloody war, whilÅ¿t Å¿he encountreth with her enemies, but were unacquainted and altogether unexperienced with warlike affaires, and marÅ¿hall diÅ¿cipline: yea, when City and Country were in great diÅ¿tractions and eminent danger, and when all things both by Å¿ea and land, were to be accompliÅ¿hed for the preÅ¿ervation thereof, with all manner of diÅ¿advantages, and the greateÅ¿t hazzard and difficulty, that men could poÅ¿Å¿ibly meet withall; and therefore I Å¿ay again all theÅ¿e brave men have the primary right to be called the repairers of the breaches, the reÅ¿torers of our pathes to dwell in.

And next unto theÅ¿e illuÅ¿trious ones, I pray good Brother looke upon the famous Citie of London, and on all the true hearted citizens in it, who Å¿tood cloÅ¿e to the Parliament in the moÅ¿t dangerous times, and firÅ¿t reÅ¿cued their Members queÅ¿tioned, and preÅ¿erved them all from the jawes of imminent danger, and after
that expoÅ¿ed themÅ¿elves their lives, fortunes, and liberties in their quarrell, and Å¿tucke cloÅ¿e to their cauÅ¿e, Å¿upplying them continually with Men, Monies, and Ammunition, and all manner of warlicke accoutrements, without whish the whole Kingdome had beene miÅ¿erable; Yea, in their owne perÅ¿ons in the Citie and in the Field they hazarded all their lives in the Parliaments and their countries Å¿ervice, Å¿o as they alÅ¿o may juÅ¿tly challenge a Å¿hare in the next place to thoÅ¿e noble Worthies above mentioned, to be counted the Repairers of our breaches, and ReÅ¿torers of our paths to dwell in; and therefore I Å¿hall deÅ¿ire you Brother, and all thoÅ¿e of your Fraternity to give the next place of honour to this Renowned Citie. And whiles I am now Å¿peaking of Å¿uch as have deÅ¿erved well, and merited the name (under God) of being preÅ¿ervers of our pathes to dwell in: I pray let us not forget out brethren the Scots whoÅ¿e faithfull Å¿ervice deÅ¿erves eternall gratitude and an everlaÅ¿ting memory, who alÅ¿o Å¿tood in the breaches when we were but in a low condition, who for our aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance expoÅ¿ed their own lives, fortunes and countries to the fury and rage of many a potent enemy, and indured incredible hardÅ¿hip at home and abroad, undergoing many miÅ¿eries, and that at Å¿uch a Å¿eaÅ¿on of the year as was enough to have killed them, to lie in the field, and made their Country a prey for the Å¿poilers, who uÅ¿ed barbarous and mercileÅ¿Å¿e cruelties upon them, many of their brave and gallant commanders and gentlemen alÅ¿o dayly looÅ¿ing their lives and wallowing in their own blood, and all for our preÅ¿ervations; and therefore they may, under God, duly challenge the third place of honour to be reputed the Repairers of our breaches and Restorers of our pathes to dwell in: whoÅ¿e kindneÅ¿Å¿e, brother, I could wiÅ¿h that thoÅ¿e of your party may never forget.

And I may not whiles I enumerate thoÅ¿e that have deÅ¿erved the name of deliverers, omit here to Å¿peak of all the faithfull PreÅ¿byterian MiniÅ¿ters in this City as well as through Country, thoÅ¿e Chariots and HorÅ¿emen of our IÅ¿rael though now forgotten, many of the which not onely ventered their lives in battell, but by holding up their hands as MoÅ¿es did when the people of IÅ¿rael fought againÅ¿t the enemy, and by the lifting up their hearts and voices to God with Å¿trong cryes made all our Armies abroad and our CounÅ¿ells at home to proÅ¿per, and all our undertakings happily to Å¿ucceed. Neither is that all, but by their wiÅ¿dome vigilancy,
and powerfull and perÅ¿waÅ¿ive preaching they were the principall means under God of keeping the people here and every where in obedience to the Parliament by reÅ¿olving their doubts, Å¿atisfying their Å¿cruples, and going before the people to their abilities, yea (many of them to my knowledge out of zeal to the cauÅ¿e) beyond their abilities in all contributions, animating and incouraging others to bring in their Plate and Moneys and whatÅ¿oever was of price and eÅ¿teem with them exhorting them now if ever to Å¿tand for their Religion, Lives, Liberties and the Liberty of the Subject: And as by their indeavours they did exceedingly promote the cauÅ¿e through City and Country; Å¿o many of them did the Parliament very good Å¿ervice in diÅ¿covering Å¿ecret and powerfull enemies by which they were diÅ¿abled to do miÅ¿chiefe. In a word I peremptorily aÅ¿Å¿ert it, that next under God the whole Kingdome are bound to be thankfull to the MiniÅ¿ters who Å¿trengthned the hands and hearts of the Å¿ouldiers everywhere to battell and made them Å¿tick cloÅ¿e to their Å¿everall Commanders and Captaines, who without their Å¿ouldiers could never have done any thing of moment for our deliverance; and all the people through the aÅ¿Å¿ociated Counties eÅ¿pecially may thank their painfull and faithfull MiniÅ¿ters that they now live in peace and tranquillity under their Å¿everall Vines and Figtrees; and therefore the condemnation of thoÅ¿e men Å¿leeps not that for all their MiniÅ¿ters care for them and their pains taken both to preÅ¿erve them in a bodily being and for converting their Å¿ouls, in lieu of thankfulneÅ¿Å¿e do not onely reproach them with odious and infamous names, but would deprive them alÅ¿o of their livelyhoods and take away their tythes from them. Such ingratitude was never heard of in any nation before, but there was eminent danger inÅ¿ued upon it; for in the Å¿econd of the Chronicles the laÅ¿t chapter, when the Lord Å¿ent his Prophets and Servants amongÅ¿t them early and late calling them to repentance, and the people deÅ¿piÅ¿ed them, it is related that they provoked God Å¿o much by it, as there was now no remedy and medicine left to cure the nation: I pray God the Å¿ame may not happen to this ungratefull nation, who you brother and your complices have inraged againÅ¿t our faithfull and zealous MiniÅ¿ters, who notwithÅ¿tanding whatÅ¿oever the Independent party can Å¿ay, may challenge alÅ¿o a Å¿hare and that a great one in that honour to be counted the Repairers of our breaches and
the ReÅ¿torers of our paths to dwell in; and all this before the battell of Yorke and Nazeby, in both which the Independents did not do all the Å¿ervice as is pretended, and who all of them have deÅ¿erved as well from the Parliament and the whole Country as before.
This, brother Burton, being premiÅ¿ed, I come now to anÅ¿wer your Charge (which as I formerly Å¿aid) I do abÅ¿olutely deny.

And here I affirme that after theÅ¿e two noble Earls, and other of our honourable and ever to be highly renowned worthies, ceaÅ¿ed from their warlike imployments and commands by Å¿ea and land; The Army which God hath Å¿ince made the preÅ¿ervative of City and Country, It is that Army under the Command of his Excellency Sir THOMAS FAIRFAX (which is imployed in all parts and quarters of this Kingdom) whom with the whole body, I honour, and every particular member thereof, as they have done worthily. And whereas you accuÅ¿e me to be an Incendiary, and Å¿ay thoÅ¿e forecited words are flaÅ¿hes and flames to fly into the face of that Army, I am ready upon oath to depoÅ¿e, that it is a falÅ¿e miÅ¿chievous Calumny conceived in the fiery brain of Å¿ome Independent, and brought forth into the world by your Å¿trong paÅ¿Å¿ion. Further I averre there is none Å¿o blind but they can diÅ¿cerne a myÅ¿tery of iniquity in your expreÅ¿Å¿ions: for it is generally known That there are many more Presbyterians then Independents in that Army, yea ten to one, which God hath now made victorious every where, and of them as valiant men as ever drew Å¿word, or wore iron, being experienced Souldiers, gallant Stormers, and as a man may Å¿ay, even the Cream of the Kindome, and the whole â€¢ eareth its denomination from the greater part, or the better, which the Independents are not.

Now looking on the Army as it is united to one head under the command of one chiefe Generall, and whether diÅ¿perÅ¿ed EaÅ¿t, WeÅ¿t, North, South, yet hath acted together to be the PreÅ¿ervative of City and Country, is that the victorious deÅ¿piÅ¿ed Army you Å¿peak of? No, no, you will not hear of that, but you divide that Army which God hath made Å¿o inÅ¿trumentall for the Kingdomes Å¿afety, and you overlook the greateÅ¿t part thereof as if they were uÅ¿eleÅ¿Å¿e men and had done nothing for the preÅ¿ervation of City and Country; this may prove the work of an Incendiary indeed, what? will you attribute all the honour of thoÅ¿e many glorious
